The people of Ufactory were kind enough to publish their robot arm design as a STEP file on grabcad.com. However, STEP files do not easily translate to the laser cutter. For that reason, I recreated the design in solidworks and exported the vector files to make it easier for those who wish to make their own U-arm. Note that the parts that have a tiny red G on them are for the gripper assembly.
For detailed assembly instructions, please go here:
http://blog.ufactory.cc/assembly-diagram-of-uarm/
Pretty self explanatory. the document titled 5mm should be cut out of a material that is 5mm thick. Likewise, the file titled 2_5mm should be cut using material 2.5mm thick.

title: Big & Tall Filament Holder Arm for Rostock MAX

description.text:
This replacement for the stock filament holder arms will accommodate filament spools up to 100mm wide. It also elevates the spool about 20mm higher than stock, so if your filament has a large radius, it won't scrape against the top plate.
.
It's in one piece, so you don't have to wrangle two of them anymore. It also looks cooler (strictly my opinion!)
.
Update - 7-2-2014: Rounded out the top edge of the arm, where it carries the spool. There should be less friction and noise now.
33% infill is adequate. Depending on your slicer, using less infill may make the part take a lot longer to print due to retraction.

comments.text: Just printed one for my Max V1.  The tip is about 1/8" too tall to fit through the hub of a 1Kg Octave ABS spool (1.25" dia), but with a little trimming it works great :-)  Thanks!
comments.author: djdelorie

comments.text: Just printed one on my Rostock Max v2, absolutely perfect fit!  Is there any way you could make one that raises the filament 1 more inch? This would allow myself (and others) to use all my Makerbot filament with the Rostock more conveniently.  Cheers!
comments.author: davidleach

In upgrading my i3 to a dual head configuration, I discovered that the standard 20mm cable chain (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:10946) didn't have the capacity for all of my wiring (2 x j heads, 2 x thermistors, 3 fans).
Scaling the 20mm chain items up by x1.25 created a nice capacity for my wiring.
I've also been using this X Endstop (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:158434) - I figured, why not save space and integrate them both together!
AGAIN - DISCLAIMER: This is for the 20mm wire chain SCALED UP x1.25 or it will not work. Pics incoming.

title: Electronic enclosure with front panel design

description.text: These are the parts associated with a tutorial on how to design an electronic enclosure with a removable front panel design.

This is a clam-shell enclosure with a removable front faceplate. The tutorial on how to design and print this is found in the article "Enclosures - 3D Printing's Killer App (Part 3 - Design enclosures with front panels)" on the Inhale3D website ( http://www.inhale3d.com )
Part 3:
http://www.inhale3d.com/2012/12/enclosures-3d-printings-killer-app-part-3-designing-enclosures-with-front-panels/ There is a two-part video tutorial showing how the enclosure parts are designed in ViaCAD 3D. The source ViaCAD files can be downloaded and modified as you see fit. The STL files can be printed, but this is effectively a fictitious design to demonstrate end-to-end how a more complex enclosure can be made. The fictitious PCB is not meant to be printed but rather is used in the tutorial for the solid-modeling and faceplate creation. It's included here for completeness and to be used if you're following along with the tutorial. The enclosure was test printed on a LulzBot AO-100, 0.35mm nozzle, 0.25mm layer height, 0.5 infill density with 2 vertical shells. GCode generated with Slic3r 0.9.7 and print controlled with Macpronterface. At these settings the main shell took a fair amount of time to print - 3+ hours but because of the rounded edges, it's worth doing a fairly high-resolution print if possible. I've made the Slic3r INI file available for download if you would like to use it as a starting point for a print - the INI file is called "Inhale3D-enclosure.ini" and is the exact config I used to print these parts. The article shows some of the flaws seen after the first print of this and what to do about them - that's the nature of this "art", things don't come out perfectly the first time, but this one was fairly close to what was intended. Thanks for checking it out. Landon Cox
http://www.inhale3d.com

comments.text: possible to do one for 2.4ghz?
comments.author: skelator

comments.text: Yes, research resonant circuits and impedance matching, and then match this length/turns to the input impedance (Zin) of your 2.4GHz transceiver.  Extrude a spiral matching the description and then subtract it from a suitable stand shape.  Ideally you would have a network analyzer to make sure this thing resonates right at where you want it, but those cost lots of money.  You can get a circuit close and then approximately tune it using varying L and C components which is a lot cheaper, but less precise (obviously).

comments.text: Always wanted to do an EDF quad but I'm guessing the flight time will be awful. you'd probably want to use outrunners of a lower Kv with high pitch blades and lots of em. if the throttle range is too big it'll make corrections difficult so it will be a bit unstable.
comments.author: Project

comments.text: There are no restorative moments on a vehicle of this type. It is by definition unstable and requires stability augmentation. An exponential adjustment on the transmitter may correct for non linear responses of control axis. The flight time is simply related to the battery capacity and current draw. Current draw is dictated by prop loading, which changes during flight. Flight times will vary*.
comments.author: Project

comments.text: Good points, I was bringing up the flight times more from an efficiency point of view. Much better to swing a big prop slowly than a tiny prop quickly. As for control, with a lower momentum held in a smaller prop a greater throttle differential would be required for changes in yaw (as compared to a large slow prop setup). greater throttle differential is restricted by ultimate thrust delivery when looking at stability across the X & Y axis, and the longer spool up and down times. Food for thought :D.

title: Shower Screen Hook - parametric
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: I was inspired by takigama's hook, http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:28075, so I needed one to fit my shower. I decided to push myself a bit in my SCAD learning and came up with this. I like the Debug concept to help visualise the bits & pieces. Now hanging a radio, back brush, face cloth, towel (on outside of course). The camera didn't cope well with the white plastic...ghost hook?

Adjust parameters to suit your need, render, export STL. Obviously the heavier the thing you want to hang the more fill you need. Print with fine layers so curves close up properly, I haven't found the optimal setting yet; but they still hang things ;). The black printed one is from an earlier iterration.
(I just uploaded v0-1 which has this squared edge in case anyone likes it) I haven't printed a double ended one yet but no reason it should have any issues.

http://flitetest.com/articles/delta-pusher-design-flight-and-build-video#sthash.C8sJpBo1.dpuf
We're just printing the battery holder and the motor mount. OK, so we're not printing the whole plane.
In the instructions page there are some notes about handling, and some modifications.

https://sites.google.com/site/projectflightd/delta-pusher
http://www.intensewalkera.webspace.virginmedia.com/ for the original pdf plan.
http://flitetest.com/articles/delta-pusher-design-flight-and-build-video#sthash.C8sJpBo1.dpuf
A big point of note with this DeltaWing is that it uses the unusual Kline-Fogelman airfoils; in this case a KFm2. The distinctive step in the wing is obvious from the photos. This supposedly gives a much greater level of lift while not unduly increasing the drag.
OK, don't get excited you're not going to be printing a whole flying wing, this project is just the motor mount and the battery/balance weight holder. I have redrawn the aircraft plans in TurboCAD and included the CAD files and A3 pdfs for the sake of completion. Thanks to IntenseWalkera for the original plans that I worked from. Other than the addition of the printed bits I have made a couple of other changes to the original design. These include embedding the receiver in the wing more firmly and turning the servos on their sides and embedding them in the wing to give a more flush finish. I intend to embed the battery alarm in the wing too, but I have not got a spare one at this time so that has yet to be done.
The printed bits are held in place with M4 or M3 machine screws and nuts, while the battery and balance weight holder has a cover cut from Polyethylene milk bottle – something nice and tough. The balance weights were made out of some lead sand cast into 8mm diameter rods and cut to size with a craft knife – don't worry its easy to do. If you're not keen on casting the lead, just get some fishing weights and hammer them to shape. I used the milk bottle plastic to cover the receiver body and hold it in place as well as make a small holder for the speed controller so that it was firmly held while also allowing air to get around it and keep it cool.
There is a 4mm thick plastic plate on the underside of the coreflute layer of the wing under the battery and balance weight holder. This was to give extra rigidity for the bolts to hold against. This was made out of waste plastic rather than printed so there are no STLs for this. It was made just big enough for the four bolts to pass through. It could just as well have been washers or wood or even a couple of layers of milk bottle plastic. Basically make it out of whatever you have to hand.
The centre of gravity has been described as being between 7 – 8 inches from the front. I found that I was fighting to keep its nose up so reduced the weight thereby moving the CoG back.
With regard to the bits and pieces on my plane here is what I have currently installed.
Motor: hexTronik 24gram Brushless Outrunner 1500kv
ESC: TURNIGY Plush 10amp 9gram Speed Controller
Battery: 1050mAh 11.1V Lipo Battery
Prop: 8x3.8
Servos: HobbyKing 939MG Metal Gear Servo 2.5kg/ 12.5g/ 0.14sec – two of these obviously
Receiver: Turnigy 9X 2.4GHz 8Ch Receiver (V2)
Extras: On Board Lipoly Low Voltage Alarm (2s~4s)
This motor is a bit smaller than recommended but the Hobbyking site suggests that it has enough thrust which it appears to have as it is fairly lively in the air. The recommended ESC/Prop/Motor combinations from the originators are;
Motor: 1300 kV blue wonder
Prop: 8x4
ESC: 18A
Battery: 1300 mAh 11.1V 3S lipo
or
Motor: RCHotDeals 2212-13 1000 kV ~ 50 gram motor
Prop: 10x5
ESC: 18A Volcano Exceed RC
Battery: 2500 mAh 11.1v 3S 25C
I suspect this last combo could make anything fly. Some post-flight observations and updates.
The third flight attempt was successful but I needed to redesign the motor mount (See motormountv2.stl) in order to get it to fly. I gave an 8degree pitch to the motor mount so that it was driving more or less through the centre of gravity. I reduced the amount of weight in the nose to just that which would fill the printed weight holder slots. This means that the centre of gravity is somewhat further back than recommended. Without measuring it too closely I would estimate it to be around the 200mm from the nose position. The motor/prop/ESC combination was pretty good and out of my 1050mAh battery I got a good long run which would have been about 15 – 20 minutes. The KFm airfoil is an interesting thing, when I let the plane glide it had a glide ratio of about 1 in 5 which is not fabulous but it is very stall resistant. The plane when coming down in an almost flared angle drifts down gently without falling left or right or losing control. As an experiment I intend the fill the gap behind the step with some ribs (either printed or hot wire cut from polystyrene.) and cover it with paper or tape. Something to turn it into something more like a conventional airfoil but I will try something resembling the KFm3 as an intermediate step. With no other changes it will be interesting to see these configurations compare. The plane handles well with very clean turns, probably owing to the nice big tails. I have had a few problems with breaking the motor mounts due to my rotten piloting. They tend to break along the printing layer lines and so to get around this I have created two other motor mount variations to add strength - one uses an M4 both through it which is probably unlikely to break, and the other is designed to make use of the wholesome goodness of wood and so has a slot through it for a stub of popsicle stick. These new motor mounts are printed with the base plate flat in an attempt to get a bit more strength from the printed bits. This means there is a bit of overhang to deal with but they print OK. I printed them with a 25% fill.

title: Printrbot Simple Metal Improved Fan Shroud

description.text: Made this improved fan shroud for the Simple Metal with a snout that directs and concentrates air closer to the nozzle. Also gave it a longer and more organic shape to better minimize the back pressure. So far it seems to give more predictable prints.

Since it's longer, the fan needs to be mounted on the other side of the mounting holes and I made a spacer piece to account for the thickness of the sheet metal. It's separate so to avoid printing a bridge on the shroud piece.
You'll need 4x 20mm M3 screws to secure everything. My kit somehow came with those extras.

description.text:
The first thing I ever designed and printed! 
There are a number of other space invaders on here already, but they're either small, or made to accept a magnet, neither of which fit my needs.
This invader is quite large. I printed it at about 70% on a not particularly well calibrated printer (it was only my third print ever) and was very happy with the results, so it should be good even for beginners.

Print the file with the layer height and infill settings of your choice. I printed mine at .3mm height with 20% infill on my barely calibrated Solidoodle2 and it turned out quite nicely.
This is an extremely large space invader, I would recommend shrinking it in your slicing software before printing (I printed at .7 size and it turned out roughly the size of my palm).

comments.author: RobertLyleSeaton

comments.text:
So if I punch you in the face because you littered, that's not assault? Unless you're a trained police officer (in which case you'd have the training to know better) you're not allowed to use force to enforce your interpretation of the law.
For example, in most locations, a little ink on the road, particularly writing a political statement, isn't "vandalism", because it's not doing any damage to the road, just writing a message in a public space. Which is, y'know, generally legal in the United States, since the Constitution protects freedom of speech. Heck, Businesses, ad campaigns, etc., paint messages on roads and sidewalks all the time, and it's legal even if it's not political speech, just advartising. It's only illegal to write messages if it breaks some specific law, such as being obscene, or libel, or if you deface something that's specifically protected, like painting over a street sign, or a work of art. In which case you still aren't allowed to use force to stop it, because the penalty for painting something is fine, or having to clean the paint off, not being physical assaulted.
So you're advocating physically assaulting someone for doing something that's legally and constitutionally protected. Instead, how about a civil discussion?

This is nearly identical to my prior version http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:3485 . It's been slightly altered so that instead of totally hollow external cubes the interior sides come up to a point - so that there is a minimum 45 degree angle support for the top part. The next version I upload will have totally solid cubes with additional improvements discussed in this blog post http://makerblock.com/2010/08/revising-the-3x2x1-rubiks-cube/ All parts are contained within a single STL. Make sure your build platform is centered as closely as you can - the STL is nearly as wide as the full platform. Before converting to GCode, I used RepG to center the STL - you should too just in case. For more reading about this puzzle cube and other nifty stuff, check out my blog at http://MakerBlock.com

• Print the STL containing all parts.
  • Drill out the holes in the two center pieces so that an M3 nut and an M3x16 bolt will fit into either side.
  • Slot two end cubes into either center cube.
  • Bolt the two halves together.
  • Affix colored stickers or, as I did, glue colored pieces of paper.
  • Scramble.
  • Unscramble.
  • LRR. http://makerblock.com/2010/06/skeinforge-ui-suggestions/#identifier_0_1590

title: Blinking Christmas Tree with a different base

description.text: The Blinking Christmas tree was one of the first prints on my new Mendel90 machine, assembled from a kit of parts from Nophead - and it turned out VERY well indeed. However, I thought that I would make a change to the base so that it could accommodate a power supply connector. I also decided against building up the multivibrator circuits and took the easy route by purchasing flashing LEDs.

The hole in the lower part of the base is 8mm diameter and takes a standard DC power connector. I used an old mobile phone mains adapter rated at 700mA and 5V - take care to get the positive and negative the right way round! The LEDs were wired as eight parallel pairs of two in series which seemed about right.
Once you have fixed the DC power connector in place, use self tapping screws, (3mm / No. 4s), to secure the top part of the base and bring out the two wires from the power connector through the hole at the top.
Once the LEDs are in place, connect them to the power leads and then screw the base to the tree. (You will need to have drilled some small holes into the base of the tree first to match the ones in the base - I tried tapping these with an M3 thread so that I could use allen key type cap head screws but ended up using self tappers - a wee bit difficult to get your screwdriver in but it all went together in the end.
I used Faberdashery Greenery Green for the tree and Woodland Brown for the base.

title: BoltMagnet doorlock
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This object is used in a geocache to provide a lock to a door which can be unlocked using magnets placed on the magnetsign on top of the lock.

Designed with TinkerCad to be printed with a 3d printer. To complete this thing, you need:
  • 1x magnet 12mm outer diameter and 6mm inner diameter
  • 1x bolt M6x25mm.
    • Construction:
  • Put the magnet around the bolt
  • Put the bolt (head up) in the cylinder
  • Put the closing cap at the bottom
  • Screw the combination to some wood where a hole is drilled to fit in the cylinder.
    • How it works:
    When one hold another magnet on the magnet sign, it will attract the bolt with the magnet arround is and thus lifting it which unlocks the door.

description.text: Spring loaded pressure plate for uniform feed regardless of filament thickness See it in action during a fast retraction http://youtu.be/HMMkCDL2KWM

More info in my blog: http://mcmos.wordpress.com/2012/12/12/power-wasp-extruder-upgrade/ What you need:
1 spring (11mm diameter)
1 M5 bolt longher than 7cm
2 printable caps Instructions:
  • cut the head of the bolt to obtain a 6cm long thread
  • cut the spring and keep a 3,5com long piece
  • print the two caps
  • untwist the original retainer and substitute the threaded screw with the new one (longher)
  • thread the lower cap, the spring and the upper cap
  • put back the original retainer
    • enjoy

title: Card Deck Box Fully Printable Snap-Together

description.text:
This card box consists out of two main parts, which snap together.
The box was originally conceived for indexcards, the catia design is however parametric. It can easily be modified to fit Bridge or Poker gaming cards, or any other card dimension and deck thickness imaginable (as long as your card is not bigger than your printer! :D) The Box can be printed support less, however there is a raft structure below the parts. For this to work please make sure to enable thin walls in your slicer software.
The raft can also be deleted if you wish to use your own, or the pre-programmed from your slicer software.
The Index Card Box has inner dimensions of 75x107.5x19mm.
The Poker Card Box has inner dimensions of 59x89x19mm.

In case you need to modify the dimensions, download all catia V5 files. Open the assembly, and enter the parameter reference part. In this part the main parameters can be accessed. The other parts use the parameters of this part as external parameters, to make sure the same parameter values are used throughout all parts.

description.text:
This is a concept of a printable 2-Axis-GoPro-Mount. It can rotate 360Â° horizontal and about 20-30Â° vertical.
It is meant to be built in the deck of a unmanned boat, so that the upper glasplate is on the same level as the deck is.

Print and assemble.
You will need 2 Servos, one Standard-Size and one Micro-Servo. The Micro-Servo is for the vertical axis, the standard-servo is for the horizontal axis.
You also need a small mirror and some tubing with threads on the inside and 12 screws that fit in the tubing. Also you'll need some stable steel wire, as bowden cable for the vertical axis. You can see that the rod in the middle needs to be sliced open, to allow for the bowden-cable to go through. 
I have designed this thing roughly about a year ago, but I havent printed this part yet, due to a misconfigured printer, but I have a GoPro now.

description.text: I found that my UP! Mini Bed support was slightly too high causing my bed to be high in the center. So I drew UP! an array of supports in slightly different heights to swap out to get it to the right height.

The standard height from my stock part I measured was 8mm. 1 - Download all the parts of different heights.
2 - Place them on a bed and print at 0.2mm on fine.
3 - With Perf Board in place measure bow of the print bed. (mine was 0.4mm)
4 - Disassemble printer and remove factory part.
5 - Replace with part of approximately less height.

A set of tools to fill easily your nespressoÂ® alternative caps. You will never pour again coffee on your table and anymore spend five minutes per capsule with this.

• Adjust coffee quantity :
    • If you want to add more or less coffee in your caps you can make a spoon with a different size. Download and edit with openscad "Nespresso_spoon.scad". In the file, you will find a variable named "ratio" actually initialized at 1.1 (10% more than the caps volume). You can incrase or decrase this value to add more or less coffee in the caps and have a more or less intense coffee
  • Adjust caps funnel size
    • If you have a different sized caps, you can adjust the size in Nespresso funnel.scad. Just adjust cap_head and cap_col to add more or less tolerence.

As depicted on assembly picture, you will need a bottom part, a top cover and 2 axes. The axes should tightly fit the top (cover) element holes. I prepared 3 axes variants with slightly different diameters - 2.7 mm, 2.8 mm and 2.9 mm. You can print all of them and check which one work the best in your printout.  
The top part is also prepared in 3 versions - loose, normal and tight. Try printing the normal variant first. When printing tight version I needed to polish up the edges with sandpaper - then I got really nice, well-fitted result.

It's always bugged me that you can't make screw threads easily with openscad's linear_extrude - and then I realized, on my bike ride home from work, that actually you can!
.
The main problem is that people usually think of a screw thread in terms of a vertical cross section, but openscad needs a horizontal cross-section for linear extrusion. But this isn't a fundamental limitation, it's a failure of imagination! So imagine cutting a screw in half with a hacksaw. Look at the shape the cut made. If you were to linearly extrude the resulting shape, with the correct twist, then you'd get the screw back, right? So we just have to figure out what the shape of that cross-section is.
.
Fortunately we can do that natively in openscad, basically by running the game backwards: make a doughnut the shape of the thread, cut it in a spiral, and look at it from above - that's your shape.
.
More rigorously: If P is the polygon you want to extrude as a thread, first of all rotationally extrude it, to get a P-shaped torus. Then intersect the torus with a helicoid of the same pitch as the threads you want (but the opposite orientation). A helicoid is what you get when you linear_extrude a thin stick, with a twist, so both of these shapes are easy to make in openscad. Now take the result of this intersection and project it onto the xy plane. This is the cross-section of the screw we were looking for. Nifty, yes?
.
I'm not saying it's efficient, or smart, or pretty, or better than any of the screw libraries - I'm just saying it's possible, and in fact conceptually simple.
.
However, I have one more observation: if you start with a polygonal thread shape and transform it as above, then the transformation I've described seems like it might just be a two-dimensional geometric inversion in some point. Under inversions, straight lines turn into circular arcs... so there's likely to be a way smarter way to do this transformation mathematically, without going through openscad's 3D system at all! Stay tuned...
.
Edit: not really sure why thingview is showing a solid cylinder... but I did notice that openscad was doing something similar if I made any of the extrusions use too many slices. Like I said, it ain't pretty yet.

comments.text: I love this mathematical approach.  I considered the question of whether a line segment can be transformed via inversion to a circle representing the helicoid intersecting a cone, and I think the answer is no, because the helicoid intersecting a cone has radius changing linearly with z (or angle), meaning the projection is not a circle.  The helicoid-intersecting-cone could be approximated by a circular arc (for a short enough segment and not-too-different radii) but in the context of openscad and STL where everything is polygons, one might as well just calculate the path directly to generate a polygon.

comments.text: Ah, I get what you're trying to say now. The crown and root are there, just maybe a little difficult to see in the pictures without a 3D model to pan around. The root section, as you mentioned, is basically the distance between the right corner of one tooth and the left corner of the next tooth. This is automatically set to (pitch - lower_flat), and not configurable directly in trapezoidal_thread because you would get physical contradictions otherwise. This is not 10%, but really 1/8 of the pitch, based on http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO_metric_screw_thread.

This model captures the beauty of Arabic calligraphy, and by switching filament a striking effect can be achieved. Although any colors may be used, a green/white print is recommended.

This is much like the other disks I have done, the primary difference being the "writing" is half the height of its predecessors.  
Using 0.3mm layer height, the first eight layers will be the disk -- I suggest white. Then switch to another color -- green is a good choice here -- and print the remaining two layers.  
Although most of the strokes should be wide enough to print, some of the details may induce failed extrusion (at least with my replicator 2) so that is something to watch for. Extrusion never failed, but my replicator 2 was unable to produce it accurately.

Inspired by Roboteernat's super simple Paperclip belt tensioner (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:4535), but not quite getting the results I wanted, I came up with this super easy and inexpensive solution to tighten my belts without new parts and, most importantly, with disassembling my printer!

You'll need 3 cable (zip) ties, two of them should be small enough to fit between the teeth of your belt and the third sould be long enough to take up the slack in your belt. Loosely zip the two small ties around your belt, then zip the larger one though them as loosely as possible. Position the large tie along the flat side of the belt, giving some thought to the position of the ratchet (center in along the top lenght is likely best, the photo's a good example of what not to do). The two smaller ties can then be aligned between two teeth as far apart as possble and tightened enough to grab the belt. You can now tighten you belt by tightening the large tie! Since you can position them ties anywhere in the belt and once trimmed they have a very low profile, you can use this methid in tight spots like a Prusa Y-stage with little difficulty. The only down side is that it's a one way adjustment. If you get it too tight, you may be able to get a needle or small screw drive into the ratchet box to release it, or cut it off and try again. For the price, it's still a good deal. *(Cable tie model borrowed from http://grabcad.com/library/cable-tie-mount without permission for illustration only, I wouldn't suggest printing it - especially if you belts ar loose!)

title: My MakerBot 3D Portrait from Dec 5, 2012
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text: This Thing is a MakerBot 3D Portrait of tom G scanned at the MakerBot Retail Store in SoHo on Dec 5, 2012.  These scans are at 1/4th the original size.

• Preview each model by clicking the thumbnail on the top left. Click on the cube to see the model in 3D.
  • Download the STL of the file you would like to print. The first thumbnail corresponds to portrait_1, and so on.
  • Open the STL in MakerWare or ReplicatorG, resize as necessary and print.

author: tom6672

description.text:
Well, another endstop holder.
I prefere those using bolts to mount the switch, that's why I redrew Simonious' endstop.
Hint: Cut a thread into the holes of the switch, so you won't need any nuts.
Switch dimensions: 20x10x5 mm, holes 2,5 mm
Holder dimensions: elevation 35 mm, overhang (M5 axis to switch center) 35 mm, similar to Simonious's
Holes diameter: 5,5 mm / 3,5 mm
Update:
It was a bad idea to put the endstop rails in here, too.
I moved them to http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:375759
Planned:
add a customizable openscad model, so one may change dimensions of the holder.

Well...
You need 2x M3x10 and 1x M5x10 plus washers and nuts.

author: TaggLee

description.text: this is a pokemon from the original 151.

i printed this at high quality with a 40% infill and i turned the speed down. the speed while extruding is at 60 and the speed while moving is at 80 i find this helps from slipping or beening to ruff with the plastic. i also used a raft and supports it took me 12 hours to print.
